title: Detective Is Convicted For His Role In Mob Killing

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whose public policy agenda has been eclipsed lately by the city's fiscal woes and the threat of a transit strike, is planning to shift some of his attention this week to the physical condition of New York City, particularly its housing. In the first of two major speeches on the subject, Mr. Bloomberg tomorrow will lay
title: Mayor Envisions Housing Revival Unmatched Since the 80's

body: A New York City police detective became an associate of a Mafia crime family and helped cover up his cousin's role in a fatal 1998 mob shooting, a prosecutor told a federal jury in Manhattan yesterday. The government says the detective, Michael Silvestri, 46, a 19-year police veteran who was assigned to the 76th Precinct in Carroll Gardens,
title: Trial Starts for Detective Charged With Cover-Up in Mob Killing

author: Tom Vanderbilt is author of ''Survival City: Adventures Among the Ruins of Atomic America.''
body: IT is a late autumn day in Bryant Park. Red and yellow leaves swirl around clusters of green folding chairs. People sit in the thin afternoon light, talking on cellphones, to others, to themselves. The scent of a piquant cigar mixes with the crisp tang of fall. As I sit in this verdantly genteel place, a whole other flurry of movement and social
title: Walker in the Wireless City

body: TUCKED into a sliver of space between two buildings on one of Greenwich Village's many crooked streets, a narrow alleyway is closed to the public by a thin black gate. title: A Village In the City Hidden in Plain Sight

body: ON a recent workday, Brooklynites lunching near Borough Hall Plaza might have wondered why a small brass band was playing oldies and why tables with old-fashioned seltzer bottles and chocolate syrup had been set up in the sun. They might also have wondered about the portly, middle-aged man in a T-shirt and a baseball cap who was standing on the
title: URBAN TACTICS; Marty! Marty! Marty!

body: THERE are events in human life that, ultimately, must always remain mysterious. The worst tragedies that beset us are often beyond comprehension and elude description. These tragedies gnaw at us, churning around inside, at once coloring all we do yet refusing to be captured and contained. Vijay Seshadri, 48, a poet born in India who now lives in
title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Man of Words, and an Event That Defies Them

body: DEEP in Red Hook, Brooklyn, down Van Brunt Street, where you can smell the salt off New York Bay, there's a new diner, the Hope & Anchor. It's a neighborhood place in a neighborhood that doesn't have a lot of people, and it needs to serve a number of purposes at once. It's a standard-issue diner breakfast spot -- eggs served all day -- and a
title: $25 AND UNDER; In a Red Hook Diner, Cheeseburgers Are Not Enough

body: It would have taken a great deal of poetic license last Friday night to describe the first car of the Manhattan-bound F train as a happening place, the place to meet that special someone. title: Tunnel Vision; Eyes Meet, Hearts Flutter. Must Be the Subway.

body: Of the 18 Civil Court judgeships up for election in New York City this November, only six are being contested in next week's Democratic primary. title: For Civil Court in Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths MORTILLARO, LOUIS F.

title: Greatest of Ease? Hardly

body: MERCIFULLY, the eligibility dispute over the Little League baseball players from Harlem didn't last long. Officials satisfied themselves that all the youngsters met the standards for living within a district's boundaries and so deserved to represent Harlem in the Little League World Series. For all the hubbub, one issue not settled was where,
title: NYC; Bronx Is Up, And Harlem Is Where?

body: JONATHAN ROSEN is making you insanely curious about his age. He looks like a kid, but he's talking full throttle about life as a people-power organizer a decade ago, as well as about the forces that led him to create the New York Unemployment Project after Sept. 11. Mr. Rosen is the director of the project, which has been giving grief to Gov.
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Rallying the Faithful Against 'Economic Apartheid'

body: The surprising drop in median income in New York City that has puzzled demographers studying the results of the 2000 census appears to be traceable in large part to immigration, according to new census data that show income declines concentrated heavily in neighborhoods in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens that have become magnets for new arrivals.
title: Immigration Cut Into Income In New York, Census Finds

body: Eight brownstones in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, were evacuated last night after elevated levels of carbon monoxide were discovered on President Street, the authorities said. The Fire Department, responding to a report of a manhole fire around 8 p.m., found the elevated levels of carbon monoxide on President Street between Court and Clinton Streets.
title: 8 Brownstones Evacuated

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Sexual Abuse At Public Pool

body: Investigators arrested the first Roman Catholic priest yesterday to be charged in New York based on the old case files that the church recently turned over to sex-abuse prosecutors. The priest, the Rev. Francis X. Nelson, 38, was handcuffed near his Harlem church and charged with molesting a 12-year-old girl at her home in Brooklyn three years ago.
title: Priest Charged From Old File On Sex Abuse

body: A CENTURY ago, Carroll Gardens was a working-class neighborhood in Brooklyn, home to thousands of Irish immigrants. In the decades before World War II, the Irish moved out and first-generation Italians moved in. title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Carroll Gardens; Area of Gardens and 19th-Century Charm

body: These Italian restaurants emphasize the food of a particular region. I COPPI (212) 254-2263; 432 East Ninth Street (between First Avenue and Avenue A); $$$; Review: 4/21/99. title: Voices From the Underground
